Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Thanks! This looks very interesting.  I think it would be better to break this into 2 patches.  The first that adds the db migration and the new index, and the second that does the conditional clause optimization.  

Also, would it be possible to link in the information that showed the full table scan against the results after this change?

Patch Set 2:

You may want to include tags once this gets in 
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/40576/

Patch Set 2:

Thanks John for for reviewing my code.

I will separate the patch into two as mentioned two as mentioned by you and submit them soon. Currently I am working on explain plans (before and after this change) will soon share them as well.

There is a small reason why I preferred to keep the adding index column migration code as part of this patch. 
Even though we create an index on owner column, the optimizer doesn't seem to use it because of the following condition in the query.

images.deleted = 0 OR images.owner = <OWNER_ID>

Hence thought owner index and query optimization re-factor code should go together.
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

LGTM, thanks. I think it would be nice if there is a performance comparison report against the change before and after.

Patch Set 10:

Hi Fei,

Few days ago, I collected the following explain plans with before and after the code change scenarios and posted it as review comment. 

Re-posting the same, 

Collected explain plans for some queries based on different scenarios (picked up from tests). The explain plans is shared at the following location:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/fmJ0laLZIYiTKHmxNIxv/

http://paste.openstack.org/raw/fmJ0laLZIYiTKHmxNIxv/ [raw]

PS: The shared link contains explain plans for queries with before and after query optimization scenarios for comparison.

Patch Set 10: (2 inline comments)

Hello Venkatesh Sampath, thanks for the improvement and refactoring, they seems better now. I have two question.
Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

Patch Set 10:

Zhi,

How about we do the indices in a separate patch? And not mix multiple purposes in this one patch?

Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

iccha,

Sorry for nit! but seems you misunderstand my purpose here.

From "http://paste.openstack.org/raw/fmJ0laLZIYiTKHmxNIxv/" I'm sure the query condition "images.status IN ('active', 'saving', 'queued', 'pending_delete', 'deleted')" be used by image-list calling with various different filters, so if we not add this necessary index to table, I really don't think this change is complete TBH.

Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This union seems to be misleading. What you really need here is indexes on columns 'is_public' and 'owner'. If you put indexes on those columns MySQL and PostgreSQL, query planners will figure how to use them (please see http://paste.openstack.org/show/48475/ and http://paste.openstack.org/show/48476/).

Patch Set 10:

Hi Zhi,

Sorry for this delayed response Zhi. 

You are right currently we do not have index on status. But before going ahead and creating an index, I wish to check will a compound index will suit better. Meanwhile, despite the index not there on 'status' column, the query seems to be performing well taking lesser time. 

Hence, request you to allow me to do some more research on introducing the status index and submit it as a separate patch as iccha suggested.

Patch Set 10:

Hi Roman,

Hi Roman,

Thanks for your valuable feedback. You are right, the query planner should automatically take care of using indexes only if both filters are available. 

'is_public' and 'owner' are filters that are not necessarily always be part of filter list. Initially (before seperating to union queries), whenever both the filter conditions were there, (is_public OR owner), the optimizer failed to identify the right indexes and instead did a full table scan. Hence in order to avoid full table scan decided to seperate them as two queries with union join. This helps to make sure the indexes are used when both these filter conditions are available.

Hope this answers your concern.

Patch Set 10:

Hi Venkatesh, thanks for you feedback.

I'm OK for this patch but I think we'd better have an index/compound-index on status column in close future after your research.

Can you change commit message as I mentioned?
Uploaded patch set 11.

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.

Patch Set 11:

Hi Zhi,

Thanks. I have removed the commit message. Soon will submit a patch for status index.

Patch Set 11: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thank you Venkatesh for the contribution!

Patch Set 11: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks good to me. 

Not approving yet, since Roman had objections in the previous patch. Roman if you can confirm that you are good with this, we can proceed.

Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm not against the patch at all, but it's not union what prevents a full table scan, but rather adding of an index on owners column. So, the code could probably a bit easier to read if didn't use explicit union here.

Anyway, I'm happy with us having all indexes we need to make queries be executed fast :)

Patch Set 11:

Actually its both. owner index and the OR clause that was used before the union query. I will try to see other ways to make the code easier. Really appreciate your review comments. Thanks Roman.

Patch Set 11: Approved

Thanks Roman, Zhi for your input.

Thanks Venkatesh for working persistently on this patch.
